feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 21 at 7:29PM EDT by NWS Wilmington OH
entry.summary:
At 729 PM EDT, strong thunderstorms were located along a line extending from near Utica to near Lancaster, moving east at 40 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 45 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Newark, Lancaster, Heath, Granville, Baltimore, Buckeye Lake, Hebron, Utica, Millersport, Pleasantville, Hanover, Harbor Hills, Marne, Fairfield Beach, Granville South, Thornport, Thurston, Kirkersville, St. Louisville, and Rushville.
This includes I-70 in Ohio between mile markers 123 and 142, and near mile marker 144.
If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a sturdy building.
To report hazardous weather conditions, go to our website at weather.gov/iln and submit your report via social media, when you can do so safely.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Licking; Fairfield

cap:parameter.value: STRONG THUNDERSTORMS WILL IMPACT PORTIONS OF NORTHEASTERN FAIRFIELD AND EASTERN LICKING COUNTIES THROUGH 800 PM EDT

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 21 at 7:17PM EDT until October 21 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Charleston WV
entry.summary:
SVRRLX
The National Weather Service in Charleston West Virginia has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Southeastern Doddridge County in northern West Virginia... Southwestern Taylor County in northern West Virginia... Northern Lewis County in northern West Virginia... North central Upshur County in northeastern West Virginia... Northwestern Barbour County in northeastern West Virginia... Harrison County in northern West Virginia...
* Until 800 PM EDT.
* At 716 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 8 miles west of Jackson Mill, or 9 miles northwest of Weston, moving east at 40 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
* Locations impacted include... Clarksburg, Weston, Bridgeport, Stonewood, Nutter Fort, Anmoore, Jackson Mill, West Milford, Lost Creek, Jane Lew, Camden, Volga, Rosemont, Century, Avon, Wolf Summit, Alum Bridge, Hodgesville, Meadowbrook, and Despard.
This includes the following highways... Interstate 79 between mile markers 95 and 126. Route 50 in West Virginia between mile markers 70 and 82. Route 33 near mile marker 1.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Barbour, WV; Doddridge, WV; Harrison, WV; Lewis, WV; Taylor, WV; Upshur, WV

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 21 at 2:26PM PDT until October 24 at 5:00AM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.
* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South Washington Coast.
* WHEN...Through late Thursday night.
* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or drowning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of children and pets. Those participating in razor clam digs should exercise caution.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE THURSDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued October 21 at 5:16PM AST until October 22 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip currents.
* WHERE...Beaches of western Puerto Rico.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water, where it becomes difficult to return to safety.

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued October 21 at 2:04PM PDT until October 22 at 5:00AM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 21 to 24 feet in the surf zone. The Beach Hazards Statement is being allowed to expire.
* WHERE...All beaches and surf of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, from 2 PM PDT Tuesday to 5 AM PDT Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Large breaking waves will create hazardous conditions along and within the surf zone, and could inundate beaches and low lying shorelines. Beach erosion is possible, and exposed infrastructure may be damaged.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Waves are likely most dangerous during the run up to high tide.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 AM PDT WEDNESDAY... ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT HAS EXPIRED

cap:parameter.value: WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 5 AM WEDNESDAY TO 5 AM PDT THURSDAY

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 21 at 4:01PM EDT until October 22 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding.
* WHERE...Florida Keys.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets and lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some seawalls and docks will be overtopped. Boaters can expect less clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost certain to contain a mix of saltwater.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree limbs could be blown down.

cap:parameter.value: WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 10 AM WEDNESDAY TO MIDNIGHT PDT WEDNESDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Frost Advisory issued October 21 at 2:37PM CDT until October 22 at 10:00AM CDT by NWS Hastings NE
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Light winds and temperatures in the low to mid 30s will result in frost formation.
* WHERE...Portions of north central Kansas and central, east central, and south central Nebraska.
* WHEN...From 10 PM this evening to 10 AM CDT Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Frost and locally sub-freezing temperatures could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Breezy northwest winds will rapidly diminish during the evening hours allowing temperatures to plummet into the lower to mid 30s late this evening and through the overnight hours.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Phillips; Smith; Jewell; Rooks; Osborne; Mitchell; Valley; Greeley; Nance; Sherman; Howard; Merrick; Polk; Dawson; Buffalo; Hall; Hamilton; York; Gosper; Phelps; Kearney; Adams; Clay; Fillmore; Furnas; Harlan; Franklin; Webster; Nuckolls; Thayer

cap:parameter.value: FROST ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 10 PM THIS EVENING TO 10 AM CDT WEDNESDAY

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued October 21 at 12:29PM PDT until October 23 at 3:00AM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 10 to 14 feet with dangerous rip currents due to a moderately long period northwest swell. High surf is likely to return Thursday night through the weekend.
* WHERE...San Luis Obispo County Beaches and Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches. Highest for northwest and west facing beaches.
* WHEN...Until 3 AM PDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats near shore.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Localized nuisance coastal flooding and beach erosion possible Wednesday around high tide between 8am and noon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Luis Obispo County Beaches; Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 AM PDT THURSDAY

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 21 at 11:58AM PDT until October 23 at 3:00AM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A moderate to long period northwesterly swell will result in breaking waves of 12 to 17 feet and an increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents. Waves locally up to 20 feet at favored breaking points.
* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast.
* WHEN...Through late Wednesday night.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should always swim near a lifeguard.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The largest breaking waves will be tonight through Wednesday where favored locations such as Mavericks may exceed 25 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 21 at 2:25PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
The combination of westerly winds of 15 mph, with gusts to 20 to 25 mph, relative humidity levels between 25 and 30 percent, and dry fuels will lead to increased fire danger across most of northeast North Carolina on Wednesday, from 11 am to 7 pm. Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged.
Residents are urged to exercise caution handling any potential ignition source...including machinery... cigarettes...and matches. Be sure to properly discard all smoking materials. Any dry grasses and tree litter that ignite will have the potential to spread quickly.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northampton; Hertford; Gates; Pasquotank; Camden; Western Currituck; Bertie; Chowan; Perquimans

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED FIRE DANGER IN EFFECT LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH EARLY WEDNESDAY EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 21 at 2:22PM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
entry.summary:
Dry and windy conditions return to the area on Wednesday behind a departing cold front today. Afternoon Relative Humidity values are expected to drop into the 25-30 percent range across NC and the VA Piedmont, with occasional wind gusts of 20 to 25 mph. This combined with dry antecedent conditions over the last month or so will result in increased fire danger across North Carolina and portions of the Virginia Piedmont. This statement is in effect from Wednesday 11am through 7pm.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. if you do burn, use extreme caution since fires can quickly get out of hand under these conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ashe; Alleghany; Surry; Stokes; Rockingham; Caswell; Watauga; Wilkes; Yadkin; Patrick; Franklin; Bedford; Amherst; Henry; Pittsylvania; Campbell; Appomattox; Buckingham; Halifax; Charlotte

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED FIRE DANGER FROM WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 21 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary: The combination of dry fuels, low relative humidity, and gusty winds will lead to increased fire danger Wednesday. Relative humidity values may drop to 25 to 30 percent, accompanied by west-southwest winds of 10 to 15 mph with gusts to 18 mph.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Robeson; Bladen; Columbus; Inland Pender; Coastal Pender; Inland New Hanover; Coastal New Hanover; Inland Brunswick; Coastal Brunswick

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED FIRE DANGER IN EFFECT WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH EARLY WEDNESDAY EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 21 at 1:38PM EDT by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
Dry and windy conditions return to the area on Wednesday behind a departing cold front. Afternoon relative humidity values are expected to drop into the 30-35% range with occasional wind gusts up to 15-20 mph. This, combined with dry conditions, will result in increased fire danger across Cherokee and Clay Counties in southwest North Carolina.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. If you do burn, use extreme caution since fires can quickly get out of hand under these conditions.

This, combined with dry conditions, will result in increased fire danger across North Carolina.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. If you do burn, use extreme caution since fires can quickly get out of hand under these conditions.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 21 at 12:55PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
Breezy westerly winds of 15 to 20 mph will overlap with relative humidities falling into the 30 to 35 percent range Wednesday afternoon. This will lead to increased fire danger for Eastern North Carolina, so an Increased Fire Danger Statement is now in effect from 11 AM to 7 PM Wednesday.
Outdoor burning is discouraged. Please refer to your local burn permitting authority on whether you can burn. If you do burn, use extreme caution and ensure fire suppression equipment is readily available.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 21 at 12:48PM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
entry.summary: The combination of westerly winds gusting to 20-25 mph, with infrequent gusts to 30 mph, relative humidity levels between 25 and 30 percent, and prolonged dryness, an increased fire danger statement is now in effect for all of central NC on Wednesday from 11 am to 7 pm. Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 21 at 9:04AM PDT until October 22 at 5:00AM PDT by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast and Southwestern Humboldt Counties.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Del Norte; Northern Humboldt Coast; Southwestern Humboldt

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE TONIGHT

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 21 at 9:45AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.
.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to past rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The river is forecast to slowly fall through mid week. However, tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline, especially later this week as northeasterly winds increase again.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest to the river on McPherson Lane.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 3.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 AM EDT Tuesday was 3.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 3.0 feet. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 20 at 10:20PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary: .Multiple rounds of heavy rain are possible for the panhandle this week as a parade of systems move over the area. Locations primarily impacted with the highest rain rates are expected to be the southern half of the panhandle. The next system, arriving Tuesday, has a 60% chance for rain rates to exceed one tenth of an inch per hour for 24 hours. Coinciding with the high wind gusts is a 30% chance for rain rates to exceed 0.2 inches per hour. Rain totals have an 80% chance to be between 1.5 and 3.5 inches. The third system late in the week has lower confidence but higher potential, with totals between 1.5 and 4.5 inches. No flooding is currently expected, but it is possible that rivers and streams will rapidly rise with each round of precipitation.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Prince of Wales Island; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island
